title: Sweetest Rejection for Honest Effort
author: Benjamin G Nechicattu
description: This Valentine's week, I didn't just confess — I curated something.
content:
On Rose Day, I gave her a rose plant. Not a bouquet that fades, but something that could grow slowly.

On Propose Day, Pride and Prejudice — because some feelings deserve borrowed words.

On Chocolate Day, chocolates.

On Teddy Day, a teddy.


By then she texted, "Let's talk."


We met at the office. No background music. No cinematic moment. Just two people and one honest conversation.

She said, "You know why I called you."

Somewhere in trying to love her, I found another version of myself. I started sketching again. Making small handmade things. Becoming an artist in my free time — not for grand gestures, but just to see her smile. I tried to make her hard days softer. To be someone who comforts.

It all came from a real place..

she said it was too much.
She said she didn't want it.
_She couldn't return that level of effort._

My head felt warm. My heart was louder than my voice. I tried to explain what I felt — the words came out uneven, crashing into each other.

She wasn't cruel. She was clear. She was sweet even when it hurt.

And that hurt in a quiet way.

Sometimes we love in full volume while the other person is listening gently, but without the same song in their heart. Effort, even when pure, can feel heavy when the feelings aren't mutual. I'm learning to be kinder to myself for going through it.

I went looking for love and found courage. I found creativity. I found that I can feel deeply and express it without hiding. Maybe that was the real gift of this Valentine's week. The sweetest rejection doesn't break you.
It reminds you that your effort is real. I really love her more than ever..

And strangely, after all of this,
**I love her more than ever —
not in expectation, not in hope,
but in acceptance.**
